sections.subtitle: Setting and achieving meaningful financial goals

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: How to set SMART financial goals
Creating action plans for goal achievement

sections.title: SMART Goal Framework
sections.content: SMART goals are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. Instead of 'save more money,' set 'save $10,000 for a down payment by December 31, 2025.' This framework makes goals actionable and increases the likelihood of success.

points.title: Specific
points.description: Clearly define what you want to achieve - not 'save money' but 'save $5,000'.

points.title: Measurable
points.description: Include numbers so you can track progress - 'pay off $2,500 in credit card debt'.

points.title: Achievable
points.description: Set challenging but realistic goals based on your current situation and resources.

sections.title: Balance Short and Long-Term Goals
sections.content: Include both immediate goals (build emergency fund) and long-term goals (retirement savings) in your financial plan for balanced progress.

sections.title: Creating Action Plans
sections.content: Break large goals into smaller, manageable steps. For a $10,000 emergency fund, this might mean saving $200 per paycheck. Set milestones and celebrate progress. Use tools like savings challenges or accountability partners to stay motivated.

sections.title: Set Your Financial Goals
steps: Write down 3-5 financial goals using the SMART framework
Prioritize goals based on urgency and importance
Break each goal into specific action steps with deadlines
Set up tracking systems and regular progress reviews

sections.title: Review and Adjust Regularly
sections.content: Life circumstances change, so revisit your goals quarterly. Celebrate achievements and adjust goals that are no longer relevant or achievable.
